At that time, the World-Honored One revealed his form and appearance again, his majestic spirit shining brightly, holding the ring of fingers in his hand, he went to the Jeta Grove Monastery and told the bhiká¹£us:
You should ordain this ring of fingers as a bhiká¹£u.

At that time, inside the city gate, there was a female elephant that was about to give birth but could not give birth in time.
The elephant's owner saw from afar that the bhiká¹£u was coming and immediately got up to welcome him.
If the bhiká¹£u can make the elephant give birth in time, he can enter the city to beg for alms;
if he cannot make the elephant give birth, he cannot enter the city to beg for alms.
The bhiká¹£u replied:

Earlier, when I entered the city to beg for alms, I encountered an elephant in labor at the city gate. It blamed me for not having the magical power to make the elephant give birth. Only then could I beg for alms.

The world has such strange events.

This Angulimala has killed countless beings before, but now he is only cursing himself. From birth until now, he has never killed a living being. Hold onto this sincere speech and let the elephant give birth without harm.

He was then allowed to enter the city. The people in the streets and alleys saw Angulimala coming. Among them were those whose parents, brothers, wives, and children were killed by Angulimala. They all came forward to seek revenge, either with knives, sticks, tiles, or stones, beating Angulimala to the point of extreme exhaustion. They broke his head, injured his body, tore his clothes, and smashed his alms bowl. He then ran out of the city without begging for food.
He returned to where the World-Honored One was, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, and explained the reasons. The Buddha knew his thoughts. Angulimala received the retribution so quickly.

At that time, the World-Honored One gradually spoke the Dharma for him. He attained the fruit of stream-entry and even arhatship with the six supernormal powers and complete penetration while sitting there.
At that time, King Prasenajit immediately assembled the four divisions of his army - cavalry, elephants, chariots, and infantry - and wanted to go to that garden to fight with Angulimala.

He left the city of Shravasti and on the way heard passersby say that the great thief Angulimala had accepted the Tathagata's teachings and become a bhikkhu. He then stopped his troops and entered the Jeta Grove monastery to meet with the Tathagata.
At that time, the World-Honored One knew that the king was coming and, using his spiritual powers, concealed Angulimala's form so that he was not revealed.
Then King Prasenajit arrived at the World-Honored One's place, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, sat to one side, and at that time the World-Honored One immediately knew and asked:
Why has the king, in full battle array with the four divisions of his army, come to this place?
The king said to the Buddha:

Within the borders there is a thief named Angulimala who relies on the wilderness to commit banditry and is tyrannical and unrestrained. Therefore, I have assembled my troops and want to go and attack him.
On the way, I heard people say:
'Angulimala accepted the Buddha's transformation and attained the stage of the path.
I wonder where he is now?'
The Buddha knew the king's thoughts and immediately withdrew his spiritual powers, causing the king to see Angulimala.
When the king saw him, he was terrified and fell to the ground. The ministers helped him up and sprinkled water on him.
The Buddha said to the king:
It is a great blessing for the king to encounter this small fear. He has already attained the fruit of arhatship.

If the king were to go to that deep garden and see his original form, with a garland of fingers on his head, his body smeared with human blood, holding a sharp sword with an angry expression, the king would be so frightened that his heart and liver would shatter and he would lose his life.
The king said to the Buddha:
The Tathagata today has subdued those who were not yet subdued and liberated those who were not yet liberated. Why is it, World-Honored One!
That person has killed countless people. How could he attain the fruit of arhatship?
The Buddha said:
There is no suffering, but there is a sequence of actions, some are ripe and some are not, some are initial and some are final.
At that time, the World-Honored One, observing past causes and conditions, spoke this verse to the great assembly:ğŸ”½If one does evil in the past, but extinguishes it with goodness,
This illuminates the world,
Like the moon emerging from clouds.

If one does evil in the past, but extinguishes it with goodness is like Angulimala, who killed countless thousands of people, but extinguished his evil with the noble eightfold path, exhausting all evil and forever eradicating its roots, ultimately becoming pure and attaining the unarisen state.
Therefore it is said, If one does evil in the past, but extinguishes it with goodness.
This illuminates the world, like the moon emerging from clouds - the world has three meanings:
First, the world of sentient beings; second, the world of the container; third, the world of the aggregates.

Just as in the autumn moon surrounded by many stars, in the midst of it alone, the bright light shines far and near, the evil bhikkhus have exhausted all evils, cultivate pure practices, and in the great assembly have extensive liberation.
Therefore it is said, Illuminating the world, like the moon when the clouds have dissipated.
If one does evil before others, one uses goodness to extinguish it. In the world, one is attached to
and contemplates the meaning of emptiness.

If one does evil before others, one uses goodness to extinguish it. In doing evil, it is all due to attachment. The wife of the Brahman raised evil towards the harmless one, all due to the mind of love.
Therefore it is said, If one does evil before others, one uses goodness to extinguish it.

Worldly attachments, contemplating their emptiness means that the mind of attachment is deep and solid, revolving in the three realms, receiving the fate of the four forms of birth, and returning to the five paths, all due to attachment and inability to let go. Practitioners discern that they are empty and not real, knowing that they are all empty and tranquil, and cannot be relied upon. Therefore, it is said, Worldly attachments, contemplating their emptiness.
Abandoning the household in youth, vigorously practicing the Buddha's teachings, this illuminates the world,
like the moon emerging from clouds.
The Buddha's sutras say:

Using the analogy of an elephant trainer, at that time the elephant trainer taught the young elephants, enjoying the wilderness and not being tamed, immediately passing away in the wilderness, and there were also middle-aged elephants that were not tamed and passed away there.
Young monks are also like this, not being taught and passing away, and elder monks not being taught and passing away.

Bhiká¹£us, you should know that this is also like this. A young elephant is tamed and then dies, a middle-aged elephant is tamed and then dies, a young bhiká¹£u is taught and then dies, and an elder bhiká¹£u is taught and attains the noble Dharma and then dies.
A young bhiká¹£u diligently cultivates the Buddha's teachings without any lapses and fully possesses the Buddha's Dharma.
What is meant by fully possessing?
Attaining the unsurpassed fruit by skipping over stages, therefore it is said, The young abandon the household life and diligently cultivate the Buddha's teachings.
Illuminating the world like the moon when the clouds disperse, just like the autumn moon's light shining far.
The young abandon the household life and diligently cultivate the Buddha's teachings. The world is attached to
and contemplates the meaning of emptiness.

Those who leave the household in youth and middle age, wish to sever attachment and love, and are respected and attended to by the devas and asuras, and are served and offered to by the garuá¸as, gandharvas, and others. Therefore, it is said, The world's love and attachment, contemplate its emptiness.
Not causing harm when alive, and not grieving at death, this is seeing the path's valor,
Do not worry in the midst of it.

Not causing harm when alive, and not grieving at death, means that since birth, one does not kill, steal, or engage in sexual misconduct, and does not commit any wrongdoings. When facing the end of life, one's consciousness is clear and still, and one is not frightened. One also does not see the hells, animals, or hungry ghosts, and does not see any evil ghosts. One only sees auspicious and wondrous signs. Therefore, it is said, Not causing harm when alive, and not grieving at death.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

This is the brave path of seeing, do not worry in the middle means that person who has seen the truth has already left the five difficulties. Although in the midst of sorrow and dejection, he is calm and unmoving, and does not wail or weep, giving rise to various afflictions. Therefore it is said, This is the brave path of seeing, do not worry in the middle.
Not causing harm when alive, and not grieving when dead, this is the brave path of seeing,
being alone and bright among relatives.

Not causing harm when alive, and not grieving when dead means that since birth, one does not engage in evil practices due to one's parents, siblings, relatives, or the five clans. Therefore it is said, being alone and bright among relatives.
Cutting off turbid and dark dharmas, learning only the pure and bright, crossing the abyss and not returning,
abandoning reliance and practicing cessation, no longer tainted by pleasure, wishing to cut off and be free from sorrow.
Cutting off turbid and dark dharmas - what are called turbid and dark dharmas?
The answer is:
All the fetters, bonds, defilements, and all the unwholesome dharmas that lead to retrogression and attachment to birth and death, should be cut off, have been cut off, and will be eternally cut off.
Therefore it is said, Cut off the turbid and dark dharmas.
What are called the pure and bright dharmas?
The answer is:

The foundations of mindfulness, the right efforts, the bases of supernatural power, the faculties, the powers, the factors of enlightenment, the eightfold noble path, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, the true dharmas that are free from birth and death and lead to liberation, are also called the pure and bright dharmas.
Therefore it is said, Study only the pure and bright.
Cross the abyss and do not return - why is it called an abyss?

What is called an abyss is the current in the realms and destinies that increases birth and death. Because of this abyss, one flows through birth and death without being able to count or record it, falling into the three evil paths and eight difficulties. Therefore the World-Honored One said, Destroy the four abysses and seek the unsurpassed path.
Therefore it is said, Cross the abyss and do not return.
Abandoning reliance and practicing cessation - what is meant by reliance?
As for reliance, it refers to relying on unwholesome dharmas of desire. Therefore, the TathÄgata says, Abandoning reliance and being unattached is called true practice.
Therefore, it is said, Abandoning reliance and practicing cessation.

No longer indulging in pleasure means not being tainted by the five kinds of pleasure, and being close to the sages' precepts without ever abandoning them. Therefore, it is said, No longer indulging in pleasure.

Desiring to cut off worries means that because people do not reach the state of no-afflictions, they all give rise to desires and become attached to female form, giving rise to thoughts and ideas, thinking of their appearance, hair, body hair, nails, teeth, plumpness, whiteness, and uprightness;
Practitioners should remove those thoughts and desires, and the thoughts of desire will then cease and no longer burn.
Therefore, it is said, Desiring to cut off worries.
The mind of desire is the field, lust, anger, and delusion are the seeds,ğŸ”½Therefore, giving to those who transcend the world,
One attains immeasurable blessings.

As for the mind of desire being the field, it is like a barren field with uncultivated soil, where weeds grow rampant and harm the good seedlings, and the grain seeds do not flourish and the harvest is not abundant. People who are attached to desire are also like this. Therefore, it is said, the mind of desire is the field.
As for lust, anger, and delusion being the seeds, a practitioner should always observe and contemplate, If a person plants merits, where should they be given to obtain the fruits of retribution?
The answer is:
Those who give to those without emptiness within are few, while those who give to those with emptiness within are many.
What does it mean to give to those without emptiness within?
The answer is:
Those who give to non-Buddhist practitioners, naked ascetics, Nirgrantha Jains, and other foolish people, hoping for blessings in return, do not obtain even a sixteenth part of the merit.
It is like a filthy field that harms good seedlings. Filthy-acting ascetics harm the roots of goodness, and because they are covered by lust, anger, and delusion, the fruits of the path do not arise.
Therefore it is said, 'Because of desire, anger, and delusion, one should practice giving to transcend the world.'

'The merit obtained is immeasurable' praises the reward of giving to the TathÄgata's noble assembly. Among the great assembly, there are those who have severed desires. Although their giving is small, they obtain immeasurable merit. The fruits and rewards they obtain are beyond calculation. Therefore it is said, 'Therefore, one who practices giving to transcend the world obtains merit that is immeasurable.'
Just like a filthy and evil field, anger and resentment grow rampant.
Therefore one should be free from anger, and the reward of giving is immeasurable.
'Just like a filthy and evil field, anger and resentment grow rampant' - why is it called filthy and evil?
The reason it is called filthy and evil is because it destroys oneself and also destroys others.
The reason it destroys oneself is that when anger and resentment are rampant, one's facial expression changes and one's original nature transforms, which is called self-destruction.
The reason it destroys others is that when anger and resentment are rampant, one harms others and even takes away their life.
Therefore it is said, Like a filthy field, anger grows rampant.

Therefore, one should avoid anger and give, the reward is immeasurable. People, due to harboring anger, later receive the retribution of anger. People, due to anger, lose their country and destroy their families, all due to anger. Those who give with kindness and virtue, giving to those without anger, obtain immeasurable blessings. Therefore it is said, One should avoid anger and give, the reward is immeasurable.
Like a filthy field, ignorance and filth grow.
Therefore, one should avoid ignorance and obtain immeasurable rewards.
Like a filthy field, ignorance and filth grow. It is like that blind person who does not see high or low ground, nor does he see good or bad colors, blue, yellow, red, or white.

This kind of sentient being is also like this. Due to the Dharma of ignorant darkness, they wrap themselves up and do not see the good and bad dharmas of the Four Truths. They cover up the wisdom-illumination and the thirty-seven factors of the path.
Non-Buddhist practitioners and Brahmins, covered by delusion, do not recognize the true path.
The noble assembly of the TathÄgata is forever free from such afflictions.
Therefore it is said, Like a filthy field, delusion grows rampant.
Therefore it is said, One should be free from delusion, and the merit obtained is immeasurable. If practitioners wish to seek freedom from delusion, where should they seek it?
The answer is:
One should seek it from the noble assembly of the TathÄgata.
Why is it so?

Because the noble assembly observes the beginning and end, whether great or small, good or bad, and discerns the Four Noble Truths with the wisdom of the eye, not missing even a hair's breadth. If one offers to the noble assembly of the TathÄgata without delusion, the reward obtained is immeasurable.
Therefore it is said, One should be free from delusion and make offerings, and the reward is immeasurable.
Like a filthy field, arrogance grows rampant.
Therefore one should be free from arrogance, and the reward obtained is immeasurable.
It is like a filthy and evil field, with arrogance and conceit growing profusely. The non-Buddhist practitioners have the most severe arrogance and conceit. Therefore, the TathÄgata spoke this verse:

The brÄhmans have much arrogance and conceit. From this life, when their lives end, they will be reborn in the six destinies: as a chicken, pig, dog, wolf, donkey, or in one of the six hells. Giving to such people does not bring any reward.
Therefore, it is said, It is like a filthy and evil field, with arrogance and conceit growing profusely.

Therefore, one should be free from arrogance. The reward obtained is immeasurable. Within the TathÄgata's great Dharma, one removes arrogance and conceit. Sometimes, wearing robes and carrying a bowl, one enters the village to beg for food, lowering one's mind and humbling oneself like a caá¹‡á¸Äla girl. The body is covered with jeweled garments worth a hundred thousand, but if one goes to someone else's house, one stands by the door and does not dare enter the house.

It is the same with the monk who despises others. He originally comes from a noble clan, but he suffers his body and cultivates the Dharma of a mendicant. He controls his mind and regulates his thoughts like holding a sharp sword. He holds a bowl in his hand like a poor person in the world. The people of JambudvÄ«pa use hair as decoration, but I, a Å›ramaá¹‡a, take it and shave it off. The people of JambudvÄ«pa are greedy for clothing, but white-robed Å›ramaá¹‡as dye it to make it colored. The people of JambudvÄ«pa who commit crimes are chased to the deep mountains, and the Å›ramaá¹‡as make the mountains and forests their homes. The one without desires practices like this, let alone the one who has attained the fruits of the path, whose mind can be moved?
Therefore it is said, one should be free from arrogance, and the reward obtained is immeasurable.
Just like a filthy and evil field, greed and desire are the vines that grow.
Therefore one should be free from greed, and the reward obtained is immeasurable.

It is like a filthy field, with greed and desire as the vines. People harbor stinginess and desire until death, and because of stinginess and desire, they may injure their life-force and die. Therefore, the wise avoid stinginess and desire. Therefore, it is said, Like a filthy field, with greed and desire as the vines, therefore one should avoid desire, and the reward obtained is immeasurable.
The six overlords, with defilement as the foremost, without defilement then depart.
The defiled one is called the foolish.
As for the six overlords, what are they?
It is said to be the mind.
Counting in order, they are called the six, and counting in reverse is also six.
As for the overlords, when the mind moves, the five [sense consciousnesses] follow and create the five sense faculties, directing and commanding the various sense bases, all created by the mind.
As the Buddha's sutras say, It is like the five sense faculties each having their own objects, not confusing or encroaching upon each other.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

The mind is the foremost of these five places. It invades the five realms, employs the five faculties, and cannot stay still. It is the most supreme and wonderful among the five things. Therefore, it is called the king.
Therefore, it is said that the six are the supreme kings.
As for being stained by stains, what is meant by being stained?
It refers to being stained by color, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas. Therefore, it is said that being stained is being stained by stains.
As for being unstained being liberation, what is meant by being unstained?
It refers to the unstained arhat.
Although it is said that the stream-enterer has exhausted all defilements and attained the purity of the Dharma eye, it is not permanently attained purity;
The arhat has permanently attained purity. Therefore, it is said that being unstained is liberation.

The defiled ones are the ignorant. The ignorant practice what they should not, and are attached to form, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas. They should contemplate but do not, and contemplate what should not be contemplated. Therefore, it is said, The defiled ones are the ignorant.
The body is like a city, with bones as the walls and flesh and blood as the plaster.
The sense doors are wide open, allowing the bandits of afflictions to run rampant.

As for the body is like a city, with bones as the walls and flesh and blood as the plaster, the so-called city uses the five skandhas as the walls, with bones as the fences and walls, and blood as the plaster. If the inner contents were to be exposed outside, one would then give rise to the contemplation of impurity and not become attached to the body, giving rise to the thought of it being unenjoyable. The skin and flesh cover the bones and adorn the form. The wise observe that there is nothing to be greedy about. Therefore, it is said, The body is like a city, with bones as the walls and flesh and blood as the plaster.
When the sense doors are wide open, the thief of afflictions gets to run wild. The eye sense door is wide open, receiving external forms, who opens it?
The answer is:

Because of not contemplating, it allows the thief of afflictions to enter and plunder the wealth of wholesome roots. The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense doors are also like this. When the mind sense door is wide open, the thief of afflictions gets to enter. Therefore, it is said, When the sense doors are wide open, the thief of afflictions gets to run wild.
When there are conditions, suffering increases; observing the three causes and bonds,

Extinguishing them through the wise assembly, not from external foolish elimination. When there are conditions, suffering increases means that when there are previous conditions, subsequent suffering increases. If there are no previous conditions, how can suffering arise?

It is like a spring giving rise to water forming a river. This is also like this. When there are previous conditions, there is the limit of suffering, gradually increasing to four hundred and four illnesses. Therefore, it is said, When there are conditions, suffering increases.

As for observing those three causes of bondage, it is like a person who encounters an event and is confined in a workshop, unable to rest. This is also like that. The five aggregates of clinging are bound by afflictions, and the mind is made to serve suffering and distress, unable to remain still. One will also experience the four hundred and four diseases. Therefore, it is said, observe those three causes of bondage.

As for extinguishing it by means of the wise assembly, if one wishes to have faith and give, one should go to the great assembly. Giving a little, one gains much merit. It is like a brave and strong man who can repel external enemies and defeat their troops, and is then called brave and strong, and receives rewards surpassing the rest of the people.

The wise assembly of the TathÄgata is also like this. It is like the ocean that receives myriad streams without rejecting small currents. Those who come to make offerings are not delighted by their use, and those who do not make offerings are also not distressed. Therefore, it is said, extinguish it by means of the wise assembly.

As for not from the removal of external foolishness, worldly foolishness and confusion have long been inverted and attached to the self, attached to the five skandhas and body, considering it a real body, just like a person who has never been bitten by a poisonous snake but does not avoid it, and one who has never been bound by afflictions but creates those actions, being tainted by external objects. Therefore, it is said, not from the removal of external foolishness.
Why is it called miscellaneous?

The reason it is said to be miscellaneous is that the meanings of the verses are explained in various ways, unlike the other verses that have a single meaning. Therefore, it is said to be miscellaneous. Chapter 17 on Miscellaneous Topics is completed.
The mind is pure and attains mindfulness, without any craving or delight, already crossing the abyss of delusion,
like a goose abandoning a pond.

The mind is pure and mindful, without craving or delight means fixing the mind on purity, always seeking skillful means to attain liberation, and contemplating this birth and death as illusory and insubstantial, always harboring fear like a blazing fire. Therefore, it is said, The mind is pure and mindful, without craving or delight.

Like geese abandoning a pond means knowing that the pond water has many dangers and is often frightened by hunters, so the birds abandon the pond and fly high to avoid these many difficulties. Therefore, it is said, Like geese abandoning a pond.

Already crossing the abyss of delusion means being obscured by the abyss of delusion, penetrating to the bone and marrow, and then seeking skillful means to permanently extinguish it without remainder. Therefore, it is said, Already crossing the abyss of delusion.
It is like a goose briefly descending from the sky, seeking to leave the evil path and reach the state of no-action.
Like a goose means fearing the many birds flying in the sky, avoiding these difficulties and seeking no-action for oneself. Therefore, it is said, Like a goose.
Temporarily descending from the sky means that the body can fly far and near without obstruction, leaving danger and seeking safety. Therefore, it is said, temporarily descending from the sky.
Seeking to leave the evil paths and reach the state of no-action.

The sages and disciples, the TathÄgata, the Perfectly Enlightened One, remove evil for people and seek to leave the evil paths, cultivate good karma, and detach from all bonds. Therefore, it is said, seeking to leave the evil paths and reach the state of no-action.

It is also called the extinction of nirvÄá¹‡a, without birth, cessation, attachment, or cutting off, always unchanging and not worn out. Those who attain concentration and practice the path are afflicted by old age and sickness, with the four hundred and four diseases constantly afflicting their bodies. Disgusted with the body of the four elements, they abandon the form of the five aggregates and enter the state of no-action.
Not practicing pure conduct, little wealth accumulated, the foolish sleep,
guarding the past and not creating new.
Formerly the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada-ÄrÄma in the country of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

At that time, the World-Honored One, having arrived at the time, put on his robe and took his alms bowl, and with his attendant Ä€nanda, saw two elderly people in the world, their appearance changed and their complexion haggard, walking with a stoop. Having seen this, the World-Honored One smiled.
At that time, Ä€nanda adjusted his robes, touched his right knee to the ground, knelt for a long time with his palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
The Buddha does not smile without reason, and when he smiles, there must be a reason. Please explain the meaning.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to Ä€nanda:
Do you see these two elderly elders?
Their appearance has changed and their complexion is haggard.
If these two people had accumulated wealth from a young age in this ÅšrÄvastÄ«, they would be the wealthiest and most powerful in ÅšrÄvastÄ«;
if they were to abandon their wives and children, give up their homes and businesses, leave the household life to study the path, they would become arhats.
If they had accumulated a little wealth up to today, they would be in the second-wealthiest family in this ÅšrÄvastÄ«;
if they were to leave the household life to study the path, they would attain the fruit of the non-returner.
If these two had been in middle age, their accumulated wealth would have been sufficient by today, and they would be in the third household;
If they had left home to study the Way, they would have attained the fruit of once-returning.
I pity these two for going against their previous wishes, abandoning the fundamental and following the superficial, with hunger, cold, and myriad hardships befalling them.
At that time, the World-Honored One contemplated this meaning and, for the sake of future beings, expounded the great illumination, speaking this verse in the great assembly:
Not cultivating pure conduct, and accumulating little wealth, like a crane in a pond,
What benefit is there in guarding the old?

It is like an old crane standing by the edge of a pond, hoping for fish to come ashore so it can catch them. It labors all day, but its wishes are not fulfilled. It does not rest its mind but ends up losing its life.

Old age has the ways of old age, and strength has the power of strength. The crane uses the ways of old age to act with the power of strength, but all day it is not successful. It only thinks of catching fish in its youth and vigor, not realizing that old age has already arrived.

Now this aged elder is also like this. He thinks back on his youthful strength, singing and dancing, playing and laughing, gambling and enjoying himself, not considering that today he is aged and decrepit, hunched over and squatting.

Remembering what he has experienced, he does not practice the Dharma of old age, but only thinks of the myriad deceptions of his youth. Therefore it is said, Like a crane in a pond, what benefit is there in guarding the old?
Do not belittle small evils as having no retribution. Although water drops are tiny,
They gradually fill a large vessel. Ordinary sins are filled, accumulated from small beginnings.

As for Do not belittle small evils as having no retribution, one should not belittle evil deeds even if they are small. Although a viper is small, it can bite a person's body and its poison can spread throughout the body, leading to the loss of life. Although poison iså¾®, if a person comes and eats it, they will die upon seeing the poison.

It is the same with this. Even if the evil is small, it obstructs people's correct practice, not reaching the ultimate, not considering the retribution to be received in the future, not willing to change from day to day, not thinking of distancing oneself from evil, and thus the evil grows. Therefore, it is said, Do not look down on small evils as having no calamity.

Even though the drops of water are tiny, they gradually fill a large vessel. It is like a large vessel held up to receive dripping water, drop after drop following one another, overflowing and filling the vessel. Therefore, it is said, Even though the drops of water are tiny, they gradually fill a large vessel.

All sins are filled, accumulated from small to large. Fools practice from small to large, playing and habituating themselves day by day, not realizing that calamity will come. Therefore, it is said, All sins are filled, accumulated from small to large.
Do not look down on small goodness as having no blessings, even though the drops of water are tiny,
they gradually fill a large vessel, all blessings are filled, accumulated from the most subtle.

Do not belittle small wholesome acts as having no blessings. If there are good people who go to temples to pay homage and seek blessings, or light lamps, burn incense, sweep and clean, perform music, hang silk banners and canopies, start with a single coin, and further encourage others to give, offering as little as a handful to the holy assembly, providing toothbrushes and pure water, or continuing the light with oil lamps.

Such small acts should not be taken lightly. Based on one's mind and consciousness, the rewards obtained are immeasurable.
